conflictDescription: User Story A allows for sharing data and alerts in shared homes respecting family wishes, while User Story B requires no data sharing without explicit user permission, including with medical staff. These goals partially conflict because A expects some data sharing under family wishes, but B demands strict consent for any sharing.
conflictingNfrPairs: Ensure ALFRED respects family privacy wishes when sharing data or alerts
Do not share any user data without explicit user permission
Ensure ALFRED respects family privacy wishes when sharing data or alerts
Require clear user consent before sharing data with medical staff
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to protect client privacy in shared homes so I can keep sensitive information safe and respect family wishes.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to never share my data with anyone, including medical staff, without my clear permission, so I feel safe and keep my privacy.

conflictDescription: The caregiver wants to manage data sharing and notifications in shared homes to protect privacy and avoid bothering others, which may involve sharing some data. The older adult wants no data shared without their clear permission, including with medical staff. The caregiver's control over data sharing could conflict with the strict no-sharing rule unless explicit consent is given.
conflictingNfrPairs: Enable caregiver to manage data sharing settings to protect privacy in shared homes
Do not share any user data without explicit user permission
Enable caregiver to manage data sharing settings to protect privacy in shared homes
Require clear user consent before sharing data with medical staff
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control notifications and data sharing in shared homes to protect privacy and avoid bothering others.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to never share my data with anyone, including medical staff, without my clear permission, so I feel safe and keep my privacy.
